docs.snippet: Friday SPANISH 'EMILY' AT HUNTER     The South American actress China Zorrilla is in town with a one-woman show that has been her biggest success. It is ''Emily'' - a Spanish translation of ''The Belle of Amherst,'' William Luce's drama about Emily...
docs.lead_paragraph: Friday SPANISH 'EMILY' AT HUNTER The South American actress China Zorrilla is in town with a one-woman show that has been her biggest success. It is ''Emily'' - a Spanish translation of ''The Belle of Amherst,'' William Luce's drama about Emily Dickinson, which starred Julie Harris on Broadway in 1976. Miss Zorrilla, who was born in Uruguay and is now based in Buenos Aires, performed it for two years in Argentina and toured with it elsewhere in Latin America. She will appear at the Hunter College Playhouse, Park Avenue at 68th Street, tonight at 8, tomorrow night at 5 and 8, and Sunday at 3 and 6 P.M. Tickets: $15 ($7 for students). Reservations: 268-1320. BIG BRITISH ART SHOW In what is billed as the largest presentation of current British art to be shown in New York, the work of more than 50 artists will be on view in the Puck Building, 295 Lafayette Street in SoHo, through Nov. 17. The exhibition, ''British Art: New Directions,'' includes painting, sculpture, graphics, fiber art and jewelry, as well as works in process by eight sculptors using such materials as metal, bricks, cardboard and neon. Admission is free. Information: 226-0608. MELODRAMA IN SOHO

docs.snippet: Uruguay's military rulers are to conduct a plebiscite and hold elections even if they cannot agree with political parties on a proposed overhaul of the Constitution, a top general was quoted Friday as saying.   A draft constitutional change was...
docs.lead_paragraph: Uruguay's military rulers are to conduct a plebiscite and hold elections even if they cannot agree with political parties on a proposed overhaul of the Constitution, a top general was quoted Friday as saying. A draft constitutional change was soundly rejected in a 1980 plebiscite, and talks with political parties on proposals to pave the way for a return to democracy in 1985 broke down recently after politicians accused the military of inflexibility.

headline.main: Uruguay General Says Vote Is On Despite Political Fight

docs.snippet: Democracy in Argentina, at Last Argentina did more Sunday than elect a President. It buried the myth of Peronist omnipotence at the polls by giving a solid majority to Raul Alfonsin, an able and committed democrat. By reaching out to a working-class...
docs.lead_paragraph: Democracy in Argentina, at Last Argentina did more Sunday than elect a President. It buried the myth of Peronist omnipotence at the polls by giving a solid majority to Raul Alfonsin, an able and committed democrat. By reaching out to a working-class electorate, Mr. Alfonsin's Radical Civic Union has won the broad mandate it needs to govern. This is inspiring news for Argentina, South America and the democratic cause.

docs.snippet: Early this week, when the United States failed in its challenge to the credentials of a delegate from Grenada, the General Assembly burst into what seemed a kind of gleeful, derisive, anti-American applause.  The incident reminded some delegates of...
docs.lead_paragraph: Early this week, when the United States failed in its challenge to the credentials of a delegate from Grenada, the General Assembly burst into what seemed a kind of gleeful, derisive, anti-American applause. The incident reminded some delegates of other such outbursts - including dancing in the aisles - that apparently showed general pleasure at American embarrassments, such as the time in 1974 when Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader, was allowed to address the Assembly and the vote in 1980 electing Nicaragua to the Security Council. Similar anti-American sentiment seemed to be operating here Wednesday when the 158-member Assembly, after agreeing to skip a debate, voted overwhelmingly to deplore the United States invasion of Grenada. Not only the Soviet bloc and the developing countries, which are often known as the ''automatic majority,'' voted in favor of the resolution; not a single member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, nor such other friendly countries as Pakistan, Thailand and Egypt, voted with the United States.

headline.main: BEHIND U.N. VOTE: HOW MUCH ANTI-AMERICANISM? News Analysis

docs.snippet: The maid enters the Copacabana Hotel room and replaces the rate card under the tabletop glass. The room just went up 15 percent, to $84. The maid says nothing. The management says nothing. It happens all the time.    November is the biggest month in...
docs.lead_paragraph: The maid enters the Copacabana Hotel room and replaces the rate card under the tabletop glass. The room just went up 15 percent, to $84. The maid says nothing. The management says nothing. It happens all the time. November is the biggest month in the history of Brazilian inflation. Government-decreed semiannual wage increases are taking effect, pushing the monthly minimum from $41 - at the current but ever-changing dollar- cruzeiro exchange rate - to $68.

headline.main: BRAZIL BATTLES INFLATION NOW AT 200% RATE

byline.original: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: China will permit an American corporation, the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, to establish a wholly owned operation there, it was announced yesterday. Previously, China has restricted foreign investment to a joint venture basis.    ''Of...
docs.lead_paragraph: China will permit an American corporation, the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, to establish a wholly owned operation there, it was announced yesterday. Previously, China has restricted foreign investment to a joint venture basis. ''Of course, this is something of an experiment both for China and for 3M,'' said Lewis W. Lehr, chairman and chief executive officer of Minnesota Mining.

docs.snippet: The four Latin American nations seeking to mediate the conflicts in Central America have drafted a treaty of peace and reconciliation for the region and hope to circulate it soon, Venezuela's Foreign Minister said today.    The Venezuelan, Jose...
docs.lead_paragraph: The four Latin American nations seeking to mediate the conflicts in Central America have drafted a treaty of peace and reconciliation for the region and hope to circulate it soon, Venezuela's Foreign Minister said today. The Venezuelan, Jose Alberto Zambrano Velasco, said in an interview that the four nations - Colombia, Mexico, Panama and Venezuela, known as the Contadora group - were seeking to move swiftly because of high tensions in the region after the American-led invasion of Grenada and because of a conviction that efforts for peace in the area had reached ''a critical moment.'' In talks last week in Caracas, he said the Venezuelan Government had found Daniel Ortega Saavedra, a member of Nicaragua's governing junta, ''very worried'' about the threat of American intervention in Central America and ''really receptive'' to suggestions for a treaty that would not only ban clandestine arms traffic and other forms of support for rebel groups but also also require steps toward democracy in Nicaragua as well as other countries. Mr. Zambrano said the Foreign Ministers of the four nations planned to meet Wednesday morning to review the treaty, which was prepared by their deputy ministers and technical experts, and that the Colombian Foreign Minister was due to arrive here late tonight for the meeting. If the draft is approved, he said, it will be submitted to Nicaragua, El Salvador, Honduras, Guatemala, and Costa Rica.

docs.snippet: This city is invaded each day by an army of 3,000 Sri Lankans. Armed with brooms and mechanized street sweepers, they advance quietly and efficiently through the city's markets and grand boulevards.  Their mission is to keep Riyadh clean.  The...
docs.lead_paragraph: This city is invaded each day by an army of 3,000 Sri Lankans. Armed with brooms and mechanized street sweepers, they advance quietly and efficiently through the city's markets and grand boulevards. Their mission is to keep Riyadh clean. The results are staggering, Saudis and foreigners agree. Ten years ago Riyadh was one of the dirtiest, dustiest cities in the Middle East. Today the city is relatively spotless. Nevertheless, Rodney R. Proto, managing director of Browning-Ferris Saudi Arabia Ltd., a joint Saudi- American venture that has a five- year, $233 million contract to clean the city, is not satisfied. The company recently began a major campaign, aimed at children, to raise public consciousness about the importance of cleanliness.

docs.snippet: Pvt. Richard Gaona of San Antonio took a bite of turkey and peered out of his tiny sentry house at the sparkling blue waters of the Gulf of Elat.    ''I don't think anyone back home even knows we are here,'' he said, now eating corn on the cob. ''But...
docs.lead_paragraph: Pvt. Richard Gaona of San Antonio took a bite of turkey and peered out of his tiny sentry house at the sparkling blue waters of the Gulf of Elat. ''I don't think anyone back home even knows we are here,'' he said, now eating corn on the cob. ''But they'd be jealous if they did. The snorkeling is fantastic.''

headline.main: G.I.'S IN SINAI TAKE A BREAK FROM THEIR BOREDOM

docs.snippet: The known death toll in the crash of a Colombian Boeing 747 here today has risen to 183, officials said. The toll made it one of the 10 worst crashes in aviation history.   Only 11 of the 194 people aboard survived the impact and fire, and four of...
docs.lead_paragraph: The known death toll in the crash of a Colombian Boeing 747 here today has risen to 183, officials said. The toll made it one of the 10 worst crashes in aviation history. Only 11 of the 194 people aboard survived the impact and fire, and four of them were in very serious condition, the officials said.

headline.main: DEATH TOLL IN THE CRASH OF 747 JET NEAR MADRID AIRPORT RISES TO 183
